that the reason they granted it
was that they had changed their mind
about the O'Nofre case
and they really wanted to review
the underlying issues of the sodomy legislation
in New York.
And in fact that was an argument
that was made in the petition by the DA.
Now some people
some events happened since that petition was filed
and when the final brief was filed
for the State of New York
the District Attorney of Buffalo
he did not argue that the sodomy statute
needed to be reconsidered.
And an interesting twist too was that
the Attorney General of the State of New York
Robert Abrams filed an amicus brief
supporting the decision of the New York Court of Appeals
that the law was unconstitutional.
So you had in effect
the State's Attorney General
and a city DA
on opposite sides of the same issue.
NGRA filed an amicus brief
in the Supreme Court
arguing that the petition was impromptly granted
and that they would just throw the whole thing out
without deciding it.
And what we're hoping is that
they are not going to read the underlying issues
because for one thing
they're not properly before the Court
there wasn't an issue in the Mueller Court decision
and secondly they were not adequately briefed
because of evidence that was not an issue.
Oral arguments have already been presented in that case
we're expecting a decision later this spring.
And depending on what happens in that case
it could have a significant impact
on litigation for a good number of years to come.
Another area of litigation that's going on
is in the area of security clearances.
Security clearances are necessary for people
many people who work for the government
or work for private industry
that do contracts with the government
generally in the areas of energy and defense.
And what security clearance means
is that the government says
that you are okay to look at classified information
to feel that you're not going to default this information.
There's different levels of security clearances.
Gay people over the years
have had a great deal of problems
getting security clearances.
And
what we found is that the government's policy
on this is somewhat inconsistent.
They do not have an interagency plan
or set of guidelines or criteria.
Each agency decides on its own
and there's an awful lot of discretion
that can be exercised.
What we found is a recent trend
where in many agencies
a person can get a security clearance.
Some agencies
so-called intelligence agencies
I call them the police agencies
the FBI, the CIA
the National Security Agency
are hanging in there tough
and they will not grant security clearances
to anybody they know as gay.
There's been some recent litigation
against the CIA.
There's one case that was filed
more than a year ago
in the District of Columbia District Court.
It's before Judge Barrington Parker
and he's been sitting on
motions for summary judgment in that case
for more than a year now.
There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles
in the U.S. District Court down there
involving John Green
who was an engineer with a company
known as TRW.
He's worked with TRW, I believe,
for 13 years
and he's never had any problems.
The CIA in fact has never said
that he leaked any information
or divulged any information
but basically what they said
was that he was gay
and that he was subject to blackmail
when he was gay
and therefore made divulged information.
So that argument breaks down
when a person says
I'm not subject to blackmail.
I'm open about my sexuality.
My family knows.
My friends know.
It's no big deal to me.
I don't know why it's a big deal to you
but to the CIA it's still a big deal
and they can't,
they just cannot understand
why there might be some kind of
or might not be some kind of problem here.
So that case is pending
in the U.S. District Court.
The government just yesterday
filed this brief,
they filed a motion to dismiss
they said the court lacked jurisdiction
to hear the case
based on solemn immunity.
They said the government did not consent
to be sued in this case
and they also said that the judiciary
would be infringing on the executive branch
of government by getting involved
in this matter.
They said the CIA had absolute discretion
to decide who gets the security clearance
and who does not.
So there will be a responsible
plea filed on that on March 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is briefly some First Amendment cases
that we're involved in.
We find that a number of gay community newspapers
like here in San Francisco
we have the Bay Area Reporter
are being censored at a number of prisons
around the country.
Prisons that want to keep in touch
with their gay communities
are not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit
that we'll probably do for a lot
of the Congressional Correctional Institute
in Kentucky and maybe one here
at the Lompoc Prison
and possibly one down in Texas as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about
is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well, I went to several
undergraduate schools, but I graduated
from Michigan State University,
which is where I first got involved
in gay political causes.
And as a student, I brought a suit
against the university for refusing
to allow us to place a banner
on the two official posts, shall we say,
of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare
with 40,000 cars a day past students' intersections.
We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week
and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it was probably
because we weren't adequately prepared
because we found out from sort of some
of our sources, post-administration,
that they had been warned by their lawyers
not to do that again next year
because they'd probably be in some pretty serious trouble.
And so the next year, we made an application
to put up the banner and it ended up
without any problems.
Now, this same school, sitting in a city
that has an anti-discrimination ordinance,
which I helped lobby for in 1971,
last year, they allowed that gay students
be kicked out of fraternities simply because
they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance,
it's not going to be worth a whole lot
and it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school,
another school in Michigan called Andrews College,
which is trying to kick out two students
because they alleged they were gay.
There's a private college in the suburb of Chicago
that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student
who's completed all the students
coursework and said this person's gay
and doesn't meet the criminal character requirements
of our schools and he can't handle his degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has official,
grant official university recognition
to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space
or any funding or any of the benefits
that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas,
right now involving the rights of students
to get recognition at their campus
and my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast
involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University
in Washington, D.C. because they would not grant recognition
to the undergraduate and to the law school
gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits
involving students as well as many other areas
that are important.
Thank you.
We can become complacent here in California.
It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a great extent may be a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community.
It's sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country,
there's still a lot of problems
and that's what National Gay Rights Advocates
is all about.
It's writing these new laws.
It's writing these new laws.
It's writing these new laws.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases
involving gay youth and their rights
to their sexuality if they have not
mutually any consent?
Because that seems to be something in California
that is sort of an issue.
And it's very difficult to consider.
Yeah.
There's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases
involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases
to take is that we basically wait
for people to come to us,
which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
If a day doesn't go by,
they don't get at least one call.
So I'm not concerned about some kind
of discrimination or adverse action.
But that particular issue
hasn't reached us yet.
The thing that you do talk about
when you say housing,
some of my members have been pointing out
that this city, Denver,
has a law that says 200 million individuals
cannot live there.
And this is often used against
gay couples.
What's the status of that?
Has anything been done about it?
We haven't had any complaints
in a long time about that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating
against gay people without being so forthright
as saying that we're not going to allow
two gay people to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation
I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay,
but it was intended to keep noise down
and to protect sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly didn't have an impact on gay people.
In some areas like that,
it's very subtle with legislation.
In some states like Virginia,
it's very blatant.
